title: Acute Appendicitis
diagnosis_topic: Inflammation of the appendix leading to an acute abdomen
setup_script: A 25-year-old man presents with 12 hours of abdominal pain that started around the umbilicus and migrated to the right lower quadrant. He has nausea and one episode of vomiting.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 118/70 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.8 C.
Tenderness at McBurney's point with guarding; positive psoas sign.
WBC 14 K/uL with neutrophilia; CRP elevated.
CT scan with IV contrast shows dilated appendix 9 mm with wall thickening and periappendiceal fat stranding; ultrasound can be used for young or pregnant patients.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO and initiates IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Piperacillin-tazobactam or ceftriaxone plus metronidazole started.
Laparoscopic appendectomy scheduled promptly; open approach for complicated cases or pregnancy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If appendix appears perforated with abscess on imaging
dynamic_flow.reply: Percutaneous drainage and antibiotics considered with interval appendectomy at 6 weeks.
Perforation and generalized peritonitis may ensue, increasing morbidity.
Antibiotics alone may be used for uncomplicated cases but carry recurrence risk.
Gastroenteritis, urinary tract infection, ovarian torsion or ectopic pregnancy in women.
Early ambulation, pain control and diet advancement; discharge typically within 24 hours.
Signs of infection or recurrence and need for follow-up appointment.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of acute appendicitis using history, exam and imaging
Initiation of preoperative management with NPO, fluids and antibiotics
Timely surgical consultation and determination of operative versus non-operative approach
Recognition of perforated appendicitis and need for drainage and interval surgery
Postoperative care and patient education on complications and recurrence
